questions.question: Question 1: Which embryological structure gives rise to the pinna?
questions.explanation:
The 1st and 2nd branchial arches give rise to the pinna (auricle) through six mesenchymal 
proliferation. These proliferations are called auricular hillocks and they fuse to form the auricle. The tissue from the second arch forms nearly all of the pinna. The tissue from the first arch forms the tragus and external auditory meatus. Image showing the development of pinna: 8 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient is incidentally noted to have the following finding. It is also present on the other 
ear. Which of the following is the cause for such abnormality?

options.a: Persistent opening of first branchial cleft

questions.explanation:
The given image showing the presence of sinus seen between the tragus and crus of the helix is 
suggestive of the preauricular sinus. It is due to improper fusion of the auricular tubercle formed 
from the first and second arches. The preauricular sinus is apparent at birth and is usually bilateral. There may be occasional 
sebaceous discharge from the punctum. It does not regress spontaneously.

questions.question:
Question 3: 4 
Sold by @itachibot When are reconstructive surgeries for congenital malformations of pinna usually performed?
questions.explanation:
Reconstructive surgeries for congenital malformations of the pinna (auricle) are usually 
performed around 5 or 6 years of age. Autologous cartilages from ribs are harvested for these 
purposes and the ideal timing is between 6-10 years. At around 3 years of age, 85% of the auricular growth is complete and the cartilaginous growth is 
almost complete by 5 years. Surgery performed on the auricle after 5 years doesn't hinder further 
growth.

questions.question: Question 4: Invagination of which of the following structures will form the external auditory meatus?
questions.explanation:
Invagination of the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory meatus. Previously, it was believed that the external auditory meatus develops from the first pharyngeal 
cleft. But recent studies suggest that the first pharyngeal arch gives rise to the external auditory 
meatus. 9 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: Examination of a child with otorrhea revealed two discharging sinuses. One was present on 
the floor of the left external auditory canal and the other on the left neck just below the angle 
of the mandible. Which of the following structures is abnormal here?
questions.explanation:
Given clinical scenario is suggestive of a collaural fistula, and the first branchial cleft is abnormal 
here. The fistula has two openings: • One situated in the neck just below and behind the angle of mandible and • The other one in the external canal or the middle ear. The track of the fistula traverses through the parotid in close relation to the facial nerve.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following structure develops from all three germ layers?
questions.explanation: Tympanic membrane develops from all three germinal layers: • Outer epithelial layer is formed by the ectoderm • Inner mucosal layer by the endoderm • Middle fibrous layer by the mesoderm

questions.question:
Question 7: 5 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the structures given below forms the eustachian tube?
questions.explanation:
The eustachian tube develops from the first pharyngeal pouch. Initially, the first pharyngeal pouch forms the tubotympanic recess. The distal part of this recess 
widens to form the middle ear cavity. The proximal part forms the eustachian tube.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following pharyngeal arches gives rise to malleus and incus?
questions.explanation:
The first pharyngeal arch gives rise to malleus and incus. Stapes superstructure is formed from the second arch whereas the stapes footplate develops from 
the otic capsule.

questions.question: Question 9: Which of the following arches gives rise to the stapes?
questions.explanation:
The stapes develop from the second arch, except for its footplate and annular ligament, which 
develop from the otic capsule.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following attains adult size before birth?
questions.explanation:
10 
Sold by @itachibot Ear ossicles attain adult size before birth. The development of the middle ear: • The ossicles are full-sized cartilage models by 15 weeks of gestation. • Endochondral ossification is complete by 25 weeks. • The middle ear is adult-sized at birth.

questions.question:
Question 11: Which of the following does not reach adult size at birth? 6 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The mastoid does not reach adult size at birth. It develops fully by 2 years of age. In infants and children up to 2 years of age, the mastoid process is not developed completely. So, 
the facial nerve lies just beneath the skin near its exit. Hence, during surgical procedures, the 
incision is given slanting posteriorly, avoiding the lower part of the mastoid. This spares the facial 
nerve.

questions.question:
Question 12: An ENT surgeon has difficulty locating the mastoid antrum due to the presence of Korner's 
septum. Which of the following sutures is persistent in this case?
questions.explanation:
The persistence of the petrosquamous suture is called Korner’s septum and it is responsible for 
the difficulty in locating the mastoid antrum and the deeper cells. Korner’s septum separates superficial squamosal cells from the deep petrosal cells. Incomplete removal of disease at mastoidectomy can occur if Korner’s septum is not 
identified. Mastoid antrum cannot be reached unless the Korner’s septum has been removed. Below is an image showing Korner's septum - 11 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 13: From which of the following structure does the saccule develop?
questions.explanation:
The saccule develops from pars inferior. The development of the inner ear begins in the 3rd week of fetal life and is completed by the 16th 
week. The surface ectoderm on each side of the rhombencephalon thickens to form otic/auditory 
placodes, which then invaginate to form the otic vesicle (otocysts). The cells of the otic vesicle differentiate to form ganglion cells, which later develop into the 
vestibulocochlear ganglia. Later each otic vesicle divides into a dorsal component called pars 
superior and a ventral component called pars inferior. Pars superior gives rise to the utricle, semicircular canals, and endolymphatic ducts. Pars inferior 
gives rise to saccule and cochlear duct. The saccule is connected to the cochlea through a narrow 
duct called ductus reuniens.

questions.question: Question 14: From how many ossification centre(s) does the inner ear develop?
questions.explanation: The inner ear develops from 14 ossification centres.

questions.question:
Question 15: When does the fetus start hearing? 7 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The fetus starts hearing in the womb of the mother by 20 weeks of gestation due to sufficient 
development of the cochlea. 12 
Sold by @itachibot Anatomy of External Ear
